en.value: What's your city like?
Describing places - Connecting words
Describing places

In this unit we will look at some useful words and expressions for describing places like apartments, houses, towns and cities. We'll focus mainly on the words below. On the following screens, try to identify them in the sentence and find their translations.
central
rural
urban
outskirts
suburbs
historical
touristy
crowded
polluted
charming
peaceful
Here's a tip!
Adrian's flat is very central, it's right by King's Cross station.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
Adrian's flat is very [k]central[/k], it's right [k]by[/k] the station.
centre
front
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I grew up in a rural area in Spain, but I also appreciate the urban lifestyle.
Select the opposite of urban.
rural
central
city
My friend Juan bought a house in the outskirts of Buenos Aires.
I live in the suburbs of Boston.

A similar word to outskirts is suburbs. We've looked at the word urban, which is an adjective relating to cities or towns. The word "suburbs" comes from the expression sub-urban areas, the areas at the edges of cities.
This means I live in the city centre.
I live in the suburbs of Boston.
The suburbs lie at the edge of a city.
True or false?
My friend Juan bought a house in the [k]o[/k][k]u[/k][k]t[/k][k]s[/k][k]k[/k][k]i[/k][k]r[/k][k]t[/k][k]s[/k] of Buenos Aires.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Our home town is very historical. We get so many tourists.
[k]Our[/k] [k]home[/k] [k]town[/k] [k]is[/k] [k]very[/k] [k]historical[/k].
Select the words in the correct order.
Our home town is very [k]historical[/k]. We get so many tourists.
history
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.

When a place attracts a lot of tourists, we can create an adjective from the word "tourist" to describe it. We mostly only use this word in spoken English. Can you guess it? If not, you can see it on the next screen.
My town is quite touristy in the summer. However, it's very peaceful in the winter.
"Touristy" is an adjective that comes from the word "tourist".
My town is quite touristy in the summer.
New York City is too crowded and polluted for me. I prefer smaller cities.
Listen to the audio. This person thinks that...
the air in New York City isn't clean.
New York City is the perfect place to live.
small cities are too crowded.
This neighbourhood is so charming, with its pretty buildings and parks.
Charming is a negative adjective.
If someone uses the adjective "charming" they give a positive opinion.
Match the adjectives with their corresponding noun.
touristy
peaceful
crowded
tourist
peace
crowd
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Elsa and James are studying in New York City.
Do you like it here?
I don't know. New York City is too [k]crowded[/k] and [k]polluted[/k] for me, I prefer smaller cities…
Yeah, I know what you mean. I grew up in a [k]rural area[/k], so I find the urban lifestyle quite difficult.
Oh, where did you grow up?
In France. My [k]home town[/k] is quite [k]touristy[/k] in the summer, but it's so peaceful in the winter.
Oh, that sounds lovely!
Yeah, it's such a [k]charming[/k] place. You should visit!
Thank you, I will!
Margaret
James
My friend Juan bought a house in the [k]outskirts[/k] of Buenos Aires.
suburbs
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the audio, the person speaking...
thinks that the neighbourhood is very nice.
doesn't like the architecture in the neighbourhood.
thinks there aren't enough parks in the neighbourhood.
I grew up in a [k]rural[/k] area in Spain, [k]but[/k] I also appreciate the urban lifestyle.
city
because
My town is quite [k]touristy[/k] in the summer.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
Complete the sentence with the word that means "in the city center"
My office is quite [k]central[/k], it's walking distance from the river.
crowded
Listen to the audio. The town mentioned is...
old and very touristy.
historical but peaceful.
newly-built and touristy.
Complete the sentence with the synonym of "suburbs" you have learned.
I live in the [k]outskirts[/k] of Beijing.
Match the words with their description.
crowded
sub-urban
rural
a busy and over-populated area
an area at the edges of a city
an area in the countryside
You have an urban lifestyle if...
you live in a city.
you live in the countryside.
you live in a rural area.
Is London very [k]polluted[/k]?
Complete the sentence with the word that means "busy and over-populated"
New York City is too [k]crowded[/k] and polluted for me, I prefer smaller cities.
sub-urban
Athens is a very [k]historical[/k] city. Thousands of [k]tourists[/k] visit it every month.
peaceful
tourist
I grew up in a rural area in Spain, but I also appreciate the [k]urban lifestyle[/k].
Grammar: Connecting words

This unit is all about connecting words. We use these a lot in English, to link our ideas. By using connecting words when speaking / writing, we can sound more fluent. You've already seen a lot of these, but in this unit we'll revise the connecting words you know, and learn some new words.
then
before / after
so
therefore
due to
because of
however
although
despite
as well (as)
also
In this sentence one event happens after another.
We signed the contract, then put down the deposit.
I met the landlord and the other tenants before I signed the contract.
We can use "before", "after" and "then" to talk about when an event happens. These connecting words refer to the order of events.
I lived in a flatshare before I owned my own house.
She moved in after you moved out.
We signed the contract, then moved into the flat.
Click on the connecting words that refer to the order of events.
She moved in [h]after[/h] you moved out.
[h]Before[/h] I signed the contract, I met the landlord and the other tenants.
We loved the house, so we put down a deposit.

Did you notice? "Before" and "after" do not need to be in the middle of a sentence. We can swap around the two parts of the sentence and use a comma. Have a look at the examples below. They mean exactly the same thing and both are correct.
I signed the contract before I met the landlord and the other tenants.
Before I met the landlord and the other tenants, I signed the contract.

We've already used the connecting word "so". It expresses the result of an event. "Therefore" is very similar, but it is more formal. We use "therefore" in written English more than in spoken English.
You have signed the contract and paid the deposit. Therefore, you can move in any day from the 30th March.
She didn't like her flatmates, so she moved out.
"Therefore" has a similar meaning to "so", but it is less formal and not used in written English.
You have signed the contract and paid the deposit, therefore you can move in any day from the 30th March.
"Therefore" has a similar meaning to "so", but it is more formal and used more in written English.
Complete the sentence with the word that is more appropriate for spoken English.
My friend recommended a nice apartment, [k]so[/k] I decided to go for a viewing.
therefore

"Because of" and "due to" both give a reason for something. We can use both at the beginning or in the middle of a sentence. "Due to" is more formal than "because of" and we use it more in written English.
The oven was broken because of the previous tenants.
The poor condition of the apartment was due to the previous tenants.
Click on the connecting words that give a reason for something.
She moved out [h]because[/h] [h]of[/h] her flatmates.
The cost of the house is [h]due[/h] [h]to[/h] its location.

We can use "despite" to link ideas which are different, for example, when one idea is positive and one idea is negative. It can go at the beginning or in the middle of the sentence. We use "despite" before a noun or a gerund (the -ing form of a verb).
Despite the price (noun), we decided to move into the flat.
We decided to move into the flat despite the price.
Despite wanting (gerund) to move in before Christmas, they finally got the keys in February.
They finally got the keys in February despite wanting to move in before Christmas.
Complete the sentence with the correct connecting word.
We pay a lot for this house, [k]despite[/k] the tiny kitchen.
although

We can also use "although" to link ideas which are different. It works in the same way as "despite", but we use "although" before a subject + verb structure. Have a look at the examples. Can you see the difference between how we use "despite" and "although"?
Although it's (subject + verb) far from town centre, we think the house is perfect for us.
We think the house is perfect for us although it's (subject + verb) far from the centre of town.
Despite the distance (noun) from the town centre, we think the house is perfect for us.
[k]Although[/k] the garden is very small, the house is nice and big.
Despite
They continued renting out their spare room, [k]despite[/k] not liking the previous tenant.
although
We can use "also" and "as well (as)" when we add extra information to our spoken / written language. They both mean "in addition (to)". You can see how we use them below.
1. "Also" goes at the beginning of the sentence or directly before the main verb.
We don't like the landlord because he never fixes anything in the house. Also, he doesn't allow pets.
I love the apartment in the city centre, but I also like the house next to the park.
2. "As well" goes at the end of a sentence.
We've signed the contract already, and paid the deposit as well.
3. "As well as" means "in addition to" and we can put it at the beginning or in the middle of a sentence, before nouns and gerunds.
As well as never paying the rent on time, the tenants are very untidy.
She's renting out her apartment, as well as working a full-time job.
Choose the word / phrase with a similar meaning to "in addition".
also
because of
therefore
Choose the word / phrase with a similar meaning to "because of".
due to
despite
although
Complete each sentence to explain how we use each connecting word.
We use "despite"
We use "due to"
We use "as well as"
to link ideas that are different. It comes before nouns or gerunds.
to give the reason for something. It is a more formal version of "because of".
to add information. It has a similar meaning to "in addition to".
Click on the X in each sentence where it is possible to place the word "despite".
[h]X[/h] moving into our house in April, X we still have lots of stuff in boxes.
X we decided to move into the flat, [h]X[/h] the price.
Choose the word / phrase with a similar meaning to "due to".
because of
therefore
then
We use [k]"before / after"[/k] to [k]indicate the order of events[/k].
"as well"
give a reason for something
Complete the sentence with a connecting word and its function.
We use [k]"as well"[/k] to [k]add extra information to a sentence[/k].
"due to"
link ideas that are different
Choose the word / phrase with a similar meaning to "in addition to".
as well as
because of
due to
Click on the connecting words that we use to link ideas that are different.
[h]Although[/h] it's far from the centre of town, we think the house is perfect for us.
We decided to move into the flat, [h]despite[/h] the price.
She moved in after you moved out.
Click on the connecting words that we use to express the result of something.
She didn't like her flatmates, [h]so[/h] she moved out.
You have signed the contract and paid the deposit, [h]therefore[/h] you can move in any day from the 30th March.
I love the apartment in the city centre, but I also like the house next to the park.
Complete the sentence with the correct connecting word.
[k]Before[/k] I signed the contract, I met the landlord and the other tenants.
Due to
Complete the sentence with a connecting word with a similar meaning to the word below.
I love the apartment in the city centre, but I [k]also[/k] like the house next to the park.
in addition
Build a sentence using the connecting word.
Although [k]the lounge and bedrooms are nice and big,[/k] [k]the kitchen and the bathroom are tiny![/k]
the lounge and bathroom being nice a big,
but the kitchen and the bathroom are tiny!
Complete the sentence by writing in the box.
[k]As well as[/k] never paying their rent on time, the tenants are very untidy.
I didn't move in [k]because of[/k] the distance from the city centre.
due to
[k]They didn't get the keys until February,[/k] despite [k]wanting to move in before Christmas.[/k]
They got the keys to their new house,
they wanted to move in before Christmas.
[k]She didn't like her flatmates,[/k] so [k]she moved out.[/k]
moving out.
She liked her flatmates,
[k]Although|Even though[/k] it's far from the centre of town, we think the house is perfect for us.
Despite
As well as [k]never paying their rent on time,[/k] [k]the tenants are very untidy.[/k]
they never pay their rent on time,
and the tenants are very untidy.
